Message.Title: He gets it!
Message.Msg: "Rep. McDermott wonders why tea party groups applied for taxpayer-funded subsidies (Raw Story) Rep. Jim McDermott (D-WA) on Tuesday questioned why tea party groups were seeking to be subsidized by the government. At a House hearing on IRS misconduct, McDermott acknowledged the federal tax agency had inappropriately used political criteria to locate nonprofit applications that needed extra review. “But as I listen to this discussion, I’d like to remind everyone what we are talking about here,” he continued. “None of your organizations were kept from organizing or silenced. We are talking about whether or not the American taxpayers would subsidize your work. We are talking about a tax break.”

Topic.Title: why are so many people so hateful and racist?

Message.Msg: Perhaps growing up in a society where certain truths are left unspoken for fear of offending the "victims" (whichever SIG is being criticized at the moment) that no one can solve the problems because merely stating contributing factors will get them called a racist (or some other "ist" on the list). So naturally when they want to rebel or seem to be "against the system" they break ALL the boundaries and run off into screeds in which they use every racist epithet they can think of. I've seen some where even the subject headings would, on moderated boards, get the poster reported.

Message.Title: GOP assault on democracy
Message.Msg: But a Texas Tea Party Republican made the headlines when he had this to say about GOP voter outreach efforts. “I’m going to be real honest with you, the Republican Party doesn’t want black people to vote if they’re going to vote 9-to-1 for Democrats,” Ken Emanuelson said.

Topic.Title: He gets it!

Message.Msg: The Tea Party groups are largely Republican but include democrats and aren't interested in lobbying for a specific candidate but for a specific goal, cutting Federal government to its Constitutionally mandated duties and, any large new areas identified where federal government is needed, that they be formalized by Constitutional Amendment. e.g, "The Procedure". You know we DO have one in this nation, even if it hasn't been used since they tried to pass the ERA. The problem is that it's DESIGNED to be slow and deliberate so that the emotions of the moment don't cause us to throw away our freedom's, and so the body politic can engage in a wide debate before such a major change to our central governing document is made. Instead over the last 40 decades we've become like every other nation, throwing away the basics of our founding documents, from England ignoring the Magna Carta to Egyptian "religious tolerance" resulting in the flight of the bulk of non-Muslim groups in that nation. Ignoring the 4th Amendment when a President was losing face, ignoring the 1st because a government official's politics so heavily influenced her job she might as well have been on the Democratic National Committee, seeking to so heavily encumber the 2nd that everyone ignores that existing Federal Gun Law is based on Congress's right to raise REVENUE, and that a revenue program that costs more to administer than it takes in via SOT's each year MIGHT be more than a bit questionable, blowing off the requirement of States to follow Federal as well as State Constitutional guidelines (10th amendment) requiring stop and ask documentation (5th) . . . I could go on but there's no point. And THAT'S what created the Tea Party, not any ONE political party, but people who are tired of living with a set of laws that directly conflict with the founding documents of this nation, and the need to make a decision about what parts, if any, of that document needs must be revised or amended.

Topic.Title: GOP assault on democracy

Message.Msg: I'd say that would be true of any racial group. A 90% turnout one way when the rest of the nation is roughly split means they weren't voting based on policy, personal, or political reasons, but purely racial ones. And these are the folks calling white folks "racist". I think a bit of self examination is in order. And calling it "9 to 1" in favor of democrats would be heavily inaccurate. It was MUCH higher than that. More like 98% in this last election in favor of Barak Obama. I remember a schtick a group did on "Why did you vote for Barak Obama" and then gave respondents (Black) multiple potential reasons, all of them McCain policies that Obama denounced and, you guessed it, a significant majority of participants couldn't tell the difference. The voted for Obama because of his stance against abortion, for a larger military, for keeping Gitmo open, against a federal healthcare system (that's the one that confused the few that clued it), etc etc etc. Or at least that's what they said. So let's modify the good Representative's statement and say "The Republican party doesn't want ANYONE going to the polls who doesn't understand WHY they're pulling the lever, and given it due consideration, pulling it for the good of the nation, not because they'll get anything out of it". That's what conservatism is all about, not religion or guns or any of those other things, it's about being Conservative with the future of the nation but not taking outrageous chances with its future despite obvious trends that would be "politically incorrect" to point out, and therefore are almost always currently ignored. (though thank god it looks like Marijuana will finally be decriminalized, and hopefully records expunged, the war on Drugs has been one of the most unconstitutional boondoggles inflicted on this nation by an overreaching industry of incarceration and criminal courts)

Topic.Title: Problems with criminalized abortion

Message.Msg: 20-Week Abortion Bill Advanced By All-Male Congressional Panel (HuffPo) Republicans in the House Judiciary subcommittee voted on Tuesday to expand Rep. Trent Franks' (R-Ariz.) proposed D.C. abortion bill to apply to the whole country and advanced the bill favorably to the full committee. The bill would ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy in the United States in all cases except those in which the mother's life is in danger. All four Democrats on the panel voted against advancing the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, arguing that it is unconstitutional and allows no exceptions for rape victims, incest victims, women whose health is endangered by a pregnancy, and cases of severe fetal anomalies. The 1973 Supreme Court decision in Roe vs. Wade protects women's ability to have an abortion up until the fetus is viable outside the womb, which is usually believed to occur around the 24th week of pregnancy.

Message.Msg: Actually the entirety of our Defense Department could be our Navy as it was supposed to be, keeping sea lanes open, with one arms of our strategic defense as no tactical threat to the US is, as you said, significant with this heavily an armed population, keep our Minuteman missiles, keep enough of the Air Force for interceptors and strategic bombers (at most we'd need two dozen bombers, maybe 180 F-22's to defend the US). So yes, there is room to cut significant fat there, but . . . we'd have to warn Europe and Asia at least 10 years before we did it so they could build up enough defenses to defend themselves. About the ONLY country that could ALMOST do it right now is South Korea. The rest would fall within a few years of the announcement to hostile neighboring states. It'd be like erasing all the "rules" that to what extent they have been enforced have been largely enforced by the US, not the UN. We're talking total global chaos, or, once we get our hand out, maybe the stew will settle. Can you live with the tens (more likely hundreds) of millions of non-US lives will be lost in the ensuing chaos? I don't think I'd have a problem with it, but I thought liberals were supposed to feel an African life is worth as much as a US life in the great scheme of things?

Topic.Title: and abolish welfare, housing, Medicaid, food stamps, Planned Parenthood and especially Obamaphones

Message.Msg: It's not the pay, its the lack of required work. Think of all that manual labor and would it could do for some infrastructure problems. Heck we could even build large black obelisks and throw them out into space just to confuse some future alien archeologist . . . just with the "unemployed" classified and given work that's within their abilities. I'd code for my good 4 functioning hours a day if it would help the government save money somewhere else. I trade because it supports the economy and because it helps keep my mind sharp . . . . so in a way I contribute to the economy, but i could do a great deal more if there was a government program that organized the severely disabled into remote work groups and taught all that could learn software engineering, how to be digital artists, etc, well, let's just say that's one development studio that I'd LOVE to run. I wonder how many people that would get off the SSDI and SSI roles and into doing seriously profitable and productive work, at least part time, some of them for the first time in their lives because their potential was ignored because who would believe someone who required 24hour care could actually be worthwhile. As for those who couldn't learn those skills, I could cull the rest for good personal care attendants, electricians, etc, relocate those to where needed (server farms, in home care positions etc). Yeah, I could probably put at least 40% of the unemployables to effective use given enough money to organize and start up, but the government can't because they'd have to write 1,000 page plus guidelines for writing the rules governing the regulations to be passed to . . . and by the time we were done we'd be right back where we started. With a dysfunctional system that willingly accepts a certain amount of fraud and resource loss rather than bother to try to scavenge what seems, to it, a mere fragment of the population.

Topic.Title: Dumbo Impeachment (Honest Idea)

Message.Msg: Dude, the money ACA set aside for the pre-existing conditions/compound conditions pool RAN OUT, and they STOPPED accepting applicants. It wasn't that Republicans "cut off the funds", it was that the program was AT LEAST twice as costly as estimated. So, the problem of how to insure the uninsurable was broken, then fixed, and in less than 6 months was broken again. This time by the very author of the fix. In software we call this "debugging", but Politicians are supposed to put effort into their legislation as if they'd only get ONE compile . . . hence no bugs allowed. It doesn't cost anything for a programmer to go in there and make a tweak and release an update. For a political machine a tweak, depending on what it is, may be harder to pass than major legislation.

Message.Msg: The cost of the VA would decrease over time since a largely demobilized America wouldn't be producing anything but Marines, Navy, Naval Aviators, Strategic Air Command (Bombers), Strategic Bombardment Command Minutemen missiles, and Strategic Naval Command, SSBN's and nuclear store aboard aircraft carriers. Currently we do NOT deploy tactical nuclear weapons on attack submarines, at least officially, so those would remain under the command of the Navy itself, with one Navy Strategic Command detachment with each Carrier group authorized to direct nuclear attacks. That'd make the Combined Nuclear Forces Group a separate and elite command composed almost entirely of officers, and the enlisted folk would be ships crew, Marines, and support and maintenance. Allow the militias up to date weaponry thats still affordable (old style anti tank guns, etc) as their "issue" weapons, and if the #$%$ truly hits the fan, we pass out more advanced weapons when they are excess to the needs of the Marine Corp. By that time we might well be able to fabricate modern weapons fast enough to arm the entire United States with them in a month. There would, aside from a group for standardizing militia training and organizing more formal training, mostly Militia officers with a VERY few Regular Army officers (who'd number in the hundreds instead of hundreds of thousands) watching to maintain interoperability requirements if the nation is again directly threatened. I could keep the seaways open with what we have now, even less I think, if we didn't give a fig about the security of our allies and if we were willing to use nuclear weapons and think of them as limited strategic or tactical weapons (hitting ToraBora with one wouldn't have been a bad idea, but we don't have an earth penetrating warhead yet) and employ them when they are the most appropriate choice. For instance Assad's chemical weapons stockpile is well clear of civilians and just the right size for a W80-1 via SLAM.

Message.Title: Mitt Romney Liar: "Pre-existing conditions are covered under my plan."
Message.Msg: "Pre-existing conditions are covered under my plan." In the biggest whopper of the night, Romney suggested that his health care proposal would guarantee coverage to Americans with pre-existing conditions. This is just not true. Under Romney, if you have a pre-existing condition and have been unable to obtain insurance coverage or if you have had to drop coverage for more than 90 days because you lost your job or couldn't afford the premiums, you would be s..h..i...........t out of luck. Insurance companies could continue to discriminate and deny you coverage, as even Romney's top adviser conceded after the debate was over.
